**Arthur Fleming Fazzin** (May 1, 1924 – April 25, 1995), better known as
**Art Fleming** , was an American actor and television host. He is most
notable for being the original host of the television [game
show](/wiki/Game_show "Game show") _[Jeopardy!](/wiki/Jeopardy! "Jeopardy!")_
,[1] which aired on [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") from 1964 until 1975.

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Art_Fleming&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

Fleming was born in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York
City").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] His parents, William and Marie Fazzin, had immigrated to the
[United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") from
[Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria"). They were a popular dance team in
[Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), who had brought their show to America. Their
son Art was a varsity letterman football player at [James Monroe High
School](/wiki/James_Monroe_High_School_\(New_York\) "James Monroe High School
\(New York\)") in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"),[2]
standing 6 foot, 4 inches (1.93 m), weighing 220 pounds (100 kg). He later
attended [Colgate](/wiki/Colgate_University "Colgate University") and
[Cornell](/wiki/Cornell_University "Cornell University") universities,[3]
starring on the [football](/wiki/American_football "American football") team,
as well as [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo "Water polo") teams at both colleges.
Fleming was a [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") veteran who
served in the [U.S. Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") for
three and a half years as the [pilot](/wiki/Aviator "Aviator") of a [patrol
bomber](/wiki/Patrol_bomber "Patrol bomber") in the
[Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean").[3]

## Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Art_Fleming&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Career")]

After leaving the Navy, Fleming became an [announcer](/wiki/Announcer
"Announcer") at a [radio station](/wiki/Radio_station "Radio station") in
[Rocky Mount](/wiki/Rocky_Mount,_North_Carolina "Rocky Mount, North
Carolina"), [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina"). Here, he
first shortened his name to "Art Fleming". His radio career later took him to
[Akron, Ohio](/wiki/Akron,_Ohio "Akron, Ohio"), and back home to New York. He
was the first announcer to deliver the [slogan](/wiki/Slogan "Slogan")
"[Winston tastes good, like a cigarette
should](/wiki/Winston_tastes_good,_like_a_cigarette_should "Winston tastes
good, like a cigarette should")" for [Winston](/wiki/Winston_\(cigarette\)
"Winston \(cigarette\)") [cigarettes](/wiki/Cigarette "Cigarette").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Art_James_Bob_Clayton_Jack_Kelly_Art_Fleming_NBC_game_show_hosts_1970.JPG/220px-
Art_James_Bob_Clayton_Jack_Kelly_Art_Fleming_NBC_game_show_hosts_1970.JPG)](/wiki/File:Art_James_Bob_Clayton_Jack_Kelly_Art_Fleming_NBC_game_show_hosts_1970.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Art_James_Bob_Clayton_Jack_Kelly_Art_Fleming_NBC_game_show_hosts_1970.JPG
"Enlarge")

A 1970 NBC publicity photo featuring [Art James](/wiki/Art_James "Art James"),
[Bob Clayton](/wiki/Bob_Clayton "Bob Clayton"), [Jack
Kelly](/wiki/Jack_Kelly_\(actor\) "Jack Kelly \(actor\)"), and Art Fleming

Fleming's acting career began at age four, when he starred in a
[Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre") play. His first
[television](/wiki/Television "Television") role was as a [stunt
double](/wiki/Stunt_double "Stunt double") for [Ralph
Bellamy](/wiki/Ralph_Bellamy "Ralph Bellamy") in the detective series _[Man
Against Crime](/wiki/Man_Against_Crime "Man Against Crime")_. In 1959 he
starred as detective Ken Franklin in the
[ABC](/wiki/Associated_British_Corporation "Associated British Corporation")
TV series _[International
Detective](/w/index.php?title=International_Detective&action=edit&redlink=1
"International Detective \(page does not exist\)")_ , credited as Arthur
Fleming. He also played [attorney](/wiki/Lawyer "Lawyer") Jeremy Pitt in _[The
Californians](/wiki/The_Californians_\(TV_series\) "The Californians \(TV
series\)")_ , an [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") [Western](/wiki/Western_\(genre\)
"Western \(genre\)") set in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco,_California
"San Francisco, California") during the gold rush of the 1850s. Fleming also
appeared in many [television commercials](/wiki/Television_commercial
"Television commercial"). He was first spotted by [Merv
Griffin](/wiki/Merv_Griffin "Merv Griffin") on a commercial for [Trans World
Airlines](/wiki/Trans_World_Airlines "Trans World Airlines"). Griffin thought
Fleming was "authoritative, yet warm and interesting", and Fleming was invited
to audition for the role of host for a quiz show Griffin was developing.
Fleming (an actor with no prior TV quiz show experience) was initially
skeptical, but his agent encouraged him to "act like a game show host" at his
audition, and Fleming ultimately won the job.[1] The show was
_[Jeopardy!](/wiki/Jeopardy! "Jeopardy!")_ , which Fleming hosted from March
30, 1964, to January 3, 1975,[4] and again from October 2, 1978, to March 2,
1979. Although often described as the "host" of the program, announcer [Don
Pardo](/wiki/Don_Pardo "Don Pardo")'s introduction of him announced, "and
here's the star of Jeopardy!, Art Fleming." As "the world's greatest quiz
show's" first host, Fleming earned two [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy
Award") nominations. While he was host of _Jeopardy!_ , Fleming never missed a
taping.

Because he hosted a quiz show, Fleming earned a reputation as being a
storehouse of trivia. While appearing as a guest star on _[Hollywood
Squares](/wiki/Hollywood_Squares "Hollywood Squares")_ (another NBC game show
in the 1960s and 1970s), Fleming was once selected as the "secret square". His
question was, "In 1938, who won the Wimbledon women's tennis championship?"
Fleming picked Helen Wills Moody, one of the three choices read to him. The
female contestant (who had selected Fleming) turned to _Hollywood Squares_ MC
Peter Marshall, saying, "Art Fleming would never lie! I agree!" He was right,
and the contestant won $11,000. Fleming later said he did not know a thing
about tennis and had guessed the answer. He hoped the contestant would
disagree, thinking he was wrong.

Throughout his career, Fleming starred in about 5,000 episodes of television
programs and 48 motion pictures. After _Jeopardy! 's_ first cancellation in
1975, Fleming returned to acting. In 1977 he played the role of [W. Averell
Harriman](/wiki/W._Averell_Harriman "W. Averell Harriman") in the movie
_[MacArthur](/wiki/MacArthur_\(film\) "MacArthur \(film\)")_ starring [Gregory
Peck](/wiki/Gregory_Peck "Gregory Peck"), and appeared in the comedy film
_[American Raspberry](/wiki/American_Raspberry_\(film\) "American Raspberry
\(film\)")_ , and also appeared in episodes of _[Starsky and
Hutch](/wiki/Starsky_and_Hutch "Starsky and Hutch")_ , _[Kingston:
Confidential](/wiki/Kingston:_Confidential "Kingston: Confidential")_ , and
the 1976 TV [miniseries](/wiki/Miniseries "Miniseries") _[The
Moneychangers](/wiki/The_Moneychangers "The Moneychangers")_.

Fleming also hosted a radio version of _[College Bowl](/wiki/College_Bowl
"College Bowl")_ for [CBS Radio](/wiki/CBS_Radio "CBS Radio") from 1979 to
1982. He hosted the NBC radio weekend magazine _Monitor_ during 1972. Fleming
reprised his role as host of _Jeopardy!_ in the 1982 movie _[Airplane II: The
Sequel](/wiki/Airplane_II:_The_Sequel "Airplane II: The Sequel")_ and in
["Weird Al" Yankovic](/wiki/%22Weird_Al%22_Yankovic ""Weird Al" Yankovic")'s
music video "[I Lost on Jeopardy](/wiki/I_Lost_on_Jeopardy "I Lost on
Jeopardy")". Fleming was also often called upon to host mock versions of
_Jeopardy!_ at [trade shows](/wiki/Trade_fair "Trade fair") and conventions.

It was reported that Fleming was asked to reprise his role as _Jeopardy!_ host
when Merv Griffin began developing a revival of the show in 1983. He declined,
later stating in 1989 that he did not like the direction the show had gone in
moving the show to [Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood "Hollywood") (being partial to
his native New York, he felt that the Hollywood setting made the show dumber
and less realistic).[5] As a result, [Alex Trebek](/wiki/Alex_Trebek "Alex
Trebek") took the position instead and has hosted the program ever since.

From 1980 to 1992, Fleming hosted a daily [radio talk show](/wiki/Talk_radio
"Talk radio") on [KMOX](/wiki/KMOX "KMOX") in [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri "St. Louis, Missouri"), which continued until
his retirement. On Sunday evenings, he occasionally co-hosted _Trivia
Spectacular_ with David Strauss, a St. Louis schoolteacher. He also hosted the
syndicated radio program _[When Radio Was](/wiki/When_Radio_Was "When Radio
Was")_.

## Personal life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Art_Fleming&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Mr. Fleming was first married to actress Peggy Ann Ellis, who worked on _[The
Merv Griffin Show](/wiki/The_Merv_Griffin_Show "The Merv Griffin
Show")_.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] They had a daughter, Jan Marie Hanna[6] and
were divorced after five years. Fleming then married Rebecca "Becky" Lynn in a
private ceremony at Norman Vincent Peale's home. Becky brought two children
into the marriage. He also had four grandchildren. In 1992, Fleming retired
and the family moved to [Crystal River, Florida](/wiki/Crystal_River,_Florida
"Crystal River, Florida"). He remained active in [charity
work](/wiki/Charitable_trust "Charitable trust"): he hosted
[fundraising](/wiki/Fundraising "Fundraising") videos for the [Citrus
County](/wiki/Citrus_County "Citrus County") [United
Way](/wiki/United_Way_of_America "United Way of America") and became involved
with the [Citrus County Abuse Shelter Association,
Inc.](/w/index.php?title=Citrus_County_Abuse_Shelter_Association,_Inc.&action=edit&redlink=1
"Citrus County Abuse Shelter Association, Inc. \(page does not exist\)")
(where Becky served as director). He also hosted a syndicated television
program, called _Senior America_ , which showcased seniors and senior
activities.

## Death and
legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Art_Fleming&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Death and legacy")]

Fleming died of [pancreatic cancer](/wiki/Pancreatic_cancer "Pancreatic
cancer") at his home on April 25, 1995, six days before his 71st birthday. His
ashes were scattered at sea.[7]

Studio 25 of [The Burbank Studios](/wiki/The_Burbank_Studios "The Burbank
Studios") is named in his honor.
